node.title: Book excerpt: "Mecca" by Susan Straight
node.description: The acclaimed novelist's latest book dramatizes an epic panorama of a multiethnic southern California facing social and environmental conflagrations.

node.title: Book excerpt: "The Candy House" by Jennifer Egan
node.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "A Visit From the Goon Squad" is back with a sequel, in which a tech giant develops a means for users to externalize and share every memory they're ever had.

node.title: 2 killed, 9 wounded in shooting at Pittsburgh party, police say
node.description: Pittsburgh police said in a news release that the shooting happened at about 12:30 a.m. during a party at a short-term rental property.

node.title: Twelve injured, 10 by gunfire, in shooting at US shopping mall
node.description: Most of those injured suffered gunshots wounds, police said, but two people were injured in a stampede of bystanders running for safety.

node.title: Safe sex drug should be made widely available - advocates
node.description: Safe sex advocates want the HIV prevention drug PrEP made more accessible after Pharmac announced it will drop its price by almost 75 percent.

node.title: Christchurch carnival rides closed after child trapped
node.description: A Christchurch carnival ride on which a child was trapped on Friday has been shut until further notice.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 5933 new community cases, ten deaths
node.description: There are 5933 new cases of Covid-19 reported in the community today, with ten further deaths.

node.title: Hurricanes squeeze past Highlanders, Chiefs outclass Moana Pasifika
node.description: The Hurricanes have narrowly edged the Highlanders 22-21 in Dunedin.

node.title: Police yet to name man shot by officers in New Plymouth
node.description: The name of a man shot dead by police in New Plymouth last night cannot yet be released, Police say.

node.title: 'An open prison': Report on asylum seekers' limbo
node.description: Asylum seekers are being set up to fail by denying them access to the same rights and supports available to other refugees, advocates say.

node.title: Australia plans to keep security ties with Solomons despite China pact
node.description: Australia will continue to cooperate with Solomon Islands on matters of security even if the Pacific island nation signs a proposed security agreement with China that Australia opposes.

node.title: Pope attends but does not preside at Easter vigil service
node.description: Easter services are taking place around the world - including at St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican, where Pope Francis used his homily to condemn the cruelty of the war in Ukraine.

node.title: Accident or murder? Wife of Pittsburgh dentist dies from fatal gunshot
node.description: When Lawrence and Bianca Rudolph traveled to Zambia on a big game hunt in 2016, no one would have imagined Bianca would never make it home — and that the journey would end years later with allegations of cover-ups, infidelity, fraud and murder.

node.title: Why does Russia keep poisoning people?
node.description: Billionaire Roman Abramovich is just the latest in a long line of people who suspect they may be the target of a Kremlin poison plot.

node.title: New Covid subvariants not 'game changers' - modeller
node.description: A Covid-19 modeller says new subvariant strains will not cause waves of new cases if it arrives in New Zealand, but will likely leave a long tail of case numbers.

node.title: Can a 911 call decide the fate of a doctor charged with wife's murder?
node.description: A prominent doctor accused of killing his wife says she fell in the shower – but investigators say blood at the scene shows it wasn't an accident.

node.title: FDA investigating Lucky Charms after reports of illness
node.description: Several hundred people have posted on a food safety website complaining of nausea, diarrhea and vomiting after eating Lucky Charms.

node.title: One dead in Taranaki police shooting
node.description: A post-mortem is being carried out on the body of a man shot by police in New Plymouth yesterday.

node.title: Fewer cancer diagnoses and surgeries at start of Omicron outbreak - report
node.description: Fewer cancer diagnoses and treatments were seen during the start of the Omicron outbreak, according to a new report.

node.title: Auckland's new Covid-19 cases not highest in NZ for first time
node.description: For the first time since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, Auckland does not have the most new daily community cases reported today.

node.title: Giant pandas celebrate 50-year anniversary of U.S.-China program
node.description: The first pair of giant pandas — Ling Ling and Hsing Hsing — arrived at the National Zoo in April 1972, as a gift from the Chinese Premier to then-First Lady Pat Nixon.

node.title: Russian ambassador covered by level of diplomatic immunity - Mahuta
node.description: The Russian ambassador can't be summoned to Parliament for questioning as he has diplomatic immunity, the Foreign Affairs Minister has told MPs.

node.title: Arrest over death of Christchurch woman
node.description: A man has been charged with murder in relation to the death of a woman in Christchurch.

node.title: Crews to make another attempt to free cargo ship stuck in Chesapeake Bay
node.description: The floor of the Chesapeake Bay has been dredged and 500 containers are being removed from the ship in preparation.

node.title: 12 injured in South Carolina mall shooting; three people detained
node.description: There are no reported fatalities as of Saturday afternoon.

node.title: South African flood victims search for bodies as toll hits 400
node.description: Extremely powerful rains battered South Africa's coast, leaving about 400 dead, 13,600 people homeless and numerous families in mourning for lost relatives.

node.title: Ukraine says fighting rages in Mariupol, blasts rattle Kyiv
node.description: Ukraine says it is trying to break Russia's siege of Mariupol as fighting rages around the city's massive steel works and port.

node.title: "Face the Nation" explores food insecurity, border crisis
node.description: For Easter, "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" explores the global food crisis caused by the war in Ukraine and how a Catholic charity is helping migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border.

node.title: 'We have a huge demand for food': Even Shanghai's billionaires can't find milk and bread
node.description: As Shanghai enters its fourth week of lockdown, Chinese elites are finding themselves trapped by extreme Covid-19 measures in a city where the welfare of lower-income residents remains unknown.

node.title: The Neptune: The missiles that struck Russia's flagship, the Moskva
node.description: Russia still claims that damage to the Moskva was caused by a fire onboard. The ship later sank.
